money_flow.statutory_basis: Ark. Const. Art. 16, § 12 (No money paid from treasury without appropriation)
Proposed Ark. Code § 19-1-101 requiring contracts funded by public funds be available to legislators
Ark. Code § 19-4-101 establishing the General Accounting and Budgetary Procedures Law

money_flow.source: General revenues and special revenues derived from highway user imposts
money_flow.statutory_basis: Ark. Code §19-5-602 establishes the County Aid Fund with distribution formula (75% equal share, 25% by population) and audit requirements
Ark. Code §25-1-101 allows the Governor to declare an emergency temporary location for the seat of government during emergencies
Ark. Code §6-1-101 requires audits of publicly funded educational institutions and review of compliance with specific finance laws and teacher pay provisions

money_flow.source: Federal Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) block grant
money_flow.statutory_basis: Ark. Code §20-76-101 defines terms relating to public assistance programs including the Transitional Employment Assistance Program, which is funded by TANF block grants and state maintenance of effort

money_flow.destination: Arkansas State Hospital and affiliated agencies
money_flow.statutory_basis: Ark. Code §20-46-101 directs the State Board of Health and the Board of Trustees of the University of Arkansas to work with the Arkansas State Hospital to implement mental health services and objectives

money_flow.destination: Arkansas Crime Information Center (recidivism report generation)
money_flow.statutory_basis: Ark. Code §12-1-101 defines recidivism and requires entities that make recidivism reports to use the definition provided

money_flow.destination: Executive, Legislative, and Judicial branches of government
money_flow.statutory_basis: Act 1 of 2025 appropriates funds from the Constitutional Officers Fund to pay for salaries and expenses of various state agencies, including the executive, legislative, and judicial branches
Ark. Code §19-6-201 et seq. and the Revenue Stabilization Law provide for distribution of state general revenue collections into various fund accounts, including the General Revenue Fund
Ark. Code §19-5-602 requires distribution of general revenue to the County Aid Fund

money_flow.source: Highway revenues (motor fuel taxes, user fees)
money_flow.statutory_basis: Ark. Const. Art. 16, § 11 and state highway laws allocate motor fuel tax revenues to the State Highway and Transportation Department Fund
State highway revenue laws distribute a portion of fuel taxes to counties for road maintenance

money_flow.intermediary: Department of Education Division of Elementary and Secondary Education
money_flow.statutory_basis: Public School Funding Act of 2003 (§ 6-20-2301 et seq.) establishes the foundation funding formula to distribute state funds to school districts based on average daily membership and other factors

money_flow.source: Higher Education Grants and Tuition income
money_flow.destination: University of Arkansas System and Arkansas State University System
money_flow.statutory_basis: Ark. Code §6-61-222 authorizes the Arkansas Higher Education Coordinating Board to allocate state appropriations to institutions of higher education
Act 517 of 2025 § operations; Ark. Code Ann. § 12-27-103
Act 517 of 2025 § operations; Ark. Code Ann. § 12-27-103

money_flow.source: Participating state agencies and school districts
money_flow.intermediary: Department of Transformation and Shared Services - Employee Benefits Division
money_flow.destination: State and Public School Life and Health Insurance Program

money_flow.source: U.S. Department of Health and Human Services
money_flow.destination: Arkansas Department of Human Services - Division of Medical Services
Arkansas Department of Human Services - PASSE Program
Department of Finance and Administration - Revenue Division
money_flow.statutory_basis: Ark. Code Ann. § 26-18-101; Revenue Stabilization Act

money_flow.destination: Arkansas Department of Human Services - Audit Compliance

authority_reference.citation: Ark. Code § 19-1-101 (proposal on contracts paid with public funds)
Ark. Code § 25-1-101 (Emergency relocation of seat of government)

authority_reference.administering_body: State Board of Health and Board of Trustees of the University of Arkansas

authority_reference.citation: Ark. Code §§ 27-70-206 et seq. (Highway Revenue Distribution)
Ark. Code § 6-20-2301 et seq. (Public School Funding Act of 2003)
authority_reference.administering_body: Arkansas Division of Elementary and Secondary Education

authority_reference.citation: Ark. Code § 6-61-222 (Higher Education Coordinating Board – Authority to allocate appropriations)

authority_reference.administering_body: Department of Transformation and Shared Services
Arkansas Department of Finance and Administration

evidence_item.claim_summary: Section 12 requires that no money shall be paid out of the state treasury until appropriated by law and only in accordance with that appropriation
The interim study proposal 2021-107 for Ark. Code §19-1-101 requires entities using public funds for contracts to make contract details available to the General Assembly.

source.title: Interim Study Proposal 2021-107 – Contracts funded by public funds

evidence_item.claim_summary: Ark. Code §19-4-101 names the chapter the 'General Accounting and Budgetary Procedures Law', establishing statewide budgeting procedures

source.title: Arkansas Code §19-4-101 – General Accounting and Budgetary Procedures Law

evidence_item.claim_summary: Ark. Code §19-5-602 creates the County Aid Fund, funded by general revenue and highway user imposts; it shall be distributed to counties with 75% equal share and 25% by population; audited by Legislative Audit

Ark. Code §25-1-101 states that whenever a due to enemy attack or threat it is imprudent or impossible to conduct affairs of state at the normal location, the Governor may declare an emergency temporary location for the seat of government and acts performed there are valid

source.title: Arkansas Code §25-1-101 – Emergency relocation of seat of government

evidence_item.claim_summary: Ark. Code §6-1-101 requires Arkansas Legislative Audit or a licensed independent accountant to audit publicly funded educational institutions and review compliance with school finance laws, teacher salary statutes, and other requirements including deposit and investment of funds

source.title: Arkansas Code §6-1-101 – Review of audit report by board

evidence_item.claim_summary: Ark. Code §20-76-101 defines terms such as assessment services, date of enrollment, diversion from assistance, education or training, employment assistance, extended support services, medical assistance (Medicaid), and the Temporary Assistance for Needy Families Program for the purposes of social services programs

Ark. Code §20-46-101 authorizes and directs the State Board of Health and the Board of Trustees of the University of Arkansas to collaborate with the Arkansas State Hospital to implement mental health services and objectives
Ark. Code §20-47-101 (formerly requiring peace officers to arrest insane or drunken persons) was repealed by Act 423 of 2017

Ark. Code §12-1-101 defines recidivism as a criminal act resulting in rearrest, reconviction, or return to incarceration within three years of release and requires entities submitting recidivism reports to use this definition

Act 1 of 2025, the General Appropriation Act, allocates funds from the Constitutional Officers Fund to pay salaries and expenses of the executive, legislative, and judicial branches for fiscal years 2025-2026

source.title: General Appropriation Act for the 2025-2026 Fiscal Year (Act 1)

evidence_item.claim_summary: The Revenue Stabilization Law directs the Treasurer to distribute general revenue collections to various fund accounts including the General Revenue Fund and County Aid Fund

source.title: Arkansas Revenue Stabilization Law (Ark. Code §§19-5-101 et seq.)

evidence_item.claim_summary: Arkansas highway revenue statutes allocate portions of motor fuel taxes to the State Highway and Transportation Department Fund and to county and city road funds

The Public School Funding Act of 2003 (Ark. Code §6-20-2301 et seq.) sets the state foundation funding for K-12 education, distributing funds to school districts based on student enrollment and other factors

source.title: Arkansas Public School Funding Act of 2003

evidence_item.claim_summary: Ark. Code §6-61-222 empowers the Arkansas Higher Education Coordinating Board to allocate state appropriations among public colleges and universities

source.title: Arkansas Code §6-61-222 – Powers and duties of the Higher Education Coordinating Board

evidence_item.claim_summary: Act 517 of 2025 appropriates state general revenue funds for the operations of the Arkansas Department of Corrections and the Division of Community Correction; the exact amounts were not accessed [UNVERIFIED]

source.title: Act 517 of 2025 – Department of Corrections Appropriation

evidence_item.claim_summary: Ark. Code § 12-27-103 establishes the Division of Correction and grants it exclusive jurisdiction over the care and custody of inmates, management of correctional facilities, and operation of classification and treatment programs【383474023035326†L76-L92】.

source.title: Arkansas Code § 12-27-103 - Division of Correction powers

evidence_item.claim_summary: Ark. Code § 21-5-414(b) requires participating entities to make monthly contributions equal to the number of budgeted state employee positions multiplied by the monthly contribution authorized by the Chief Fiscal Officer to defray the cost of life and health benefits for state employees【323591194100921†L74-L85】.

The annual appropriation act for cabinet departments and independent agencies includes funding for state employee health insurance contributions; however the specific amounts were not accessible [UNVERIFIED]

source.title: FY25 AOP for Cabinet Departments and Independent Agencies
source.issuing_body: Arkansas Department of Finance and Administration

evidence_item.claim_summary: Section 1396d of the Social Security Act authorizes federal matching payments to states for medical assistance, establishing the federal medical assistance percentage (FMAP) for Medicaid.

23 U.S.C. § 104 provides for the apportionment of federal highway funding from the Highway Trust Fund to states for the National Highway System, surface transportation programs, and other initiatives.

20 U.S.C. § 6301 states the purpose of Title I of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act (ESEA) to ensure that all children have a fair, equitable, and significant opportunity to obtain a high-quality education and reach proficiency on state academic assessments.
Arkansas receives substantial federal funding including Medicaid FMAP, federal highway funds, and federal education grants; specific amounts for FY2026 were not accessed [UNVERIFIED]

source.title: Federal Grants to Arkansas – Summary
source.issuing_body: Arkansas Department of Finance and Administration

evidence_item.claim_summary: Ark. Code § 21-1-101(a)-(b) provides that time spent by employees in the U.S. Armed Forces between September 16, 1940, and December 31, 1946, counts toward length of service for pensions and other rights under civil service systems for employees of state, county, or municipal agencies supported with tax funds【576506447194482†L71-L82】.

source.title: Arkansas Code § 21-1-101 - Computation of length of service

evidence_item.claim_summary: The County Aid Fund is distributed with seventy-five percent (75%) divided equally among the seventy-five counties and twenty-five percent (25%) distributed based on population; funds are allocated by the Treasurer of State according to the formula (exact statute text not accessed) [UNVERIFIED]

Under Ark. Code § 26-26-310(a)(3), funds received by county treasurers from the Property Tax Relief Trust Fund are credited to the county property tax relief fund; 96% of the funds are distributed to taxing entities within the county and 4% retained as the commission of the county collector【462707022258521†L123-L137】.

source.title: Arkansas Code § 26-26-310 - Certification of property tax reduction

evidence_item.claim_summary: Ark. Code § 14-1-101 provides general provisions for local government; the specific section relating to municipal aid funding was not accessible [UNVERIFIED]
The Municipal Aid Fund receives general revenues and special revenues and is distributed to municipalities based on population and other formulas (exact statute text not accessed) [UNVERIFIED]

Under Ark. Code § 26-26-310(b)(2)(C)(ii)(d), two million dollars ($2,000,000) from the Property Tax Relief Trust Fund shall be distributed to municipalities using the formula stated in § 19-5-601(c)【462707022258521†L170-L175】.

source.title: Arkansas Code § 26-26-310 - Certification of property tax reduction

evidence_item.claim_summary: Ark. Code § 10-3-309(a)-(c) states that the purpose of the section is to establish a method for legislative review of state agency rules, ensuring the General Assembly can be informed when rules do not conform to legislative intent and allowing the Legislative Council to study proposed rules and advise the General Assembly【263005146388160†L71-L107】.

source.title: Arkansas Code § 10-3-309 - Review of state agency rules

evidence_item.claim_summary: The General Appropriation Act of 2025 provides general revenue funds for operations of the Arkansas Legislative Council and its staff; specific amounts were not accessed [UNVERIFIED]

Ark. Code § 19-11-203(1) defines an 'agency procurement official' as any person authorized by a state agency to enter into and administer contracts and make written determinations and findings with respect to contracts in accordance with procedures prescribed by the Arkansas Procurement Law and rules【896303631564306†L70-L77】.
The Arkansas Procurement Office receives general revenue funds for operations; specific appropriation amounts for FY2026 were not accessed [UNVERIFIED]

Ark. Code § 10-4-401(a)-(b) creates the Arkansas Legislative Audit as an agency under the General Assembly and states that it shall be headed by the Legislative Auditor selected by the Legislative Joint Auditing Committee【227353567332190†L71-L77】.

source.title: Arkansas Code § 10-4-401 - Arkansas Legislative Audit - Creation

evidence_item.claim_summary: The General Appropriation Act of 2025 provides funding for operations of the Arkansas Legislative Audit; specific amounts were not accessed [UNVERIFIED]

Ark. Code § 19-12-112 creates the Medicaid Expansion Program Account within the Tobacco Settlement Program Fund and specifies that it shall be used by the Department of Human Services for Medicaid expansion purposes and cannot supplant other funds; transfers from the Program Fund occur on July 1 and moneys must be used according to law【683287192932595†L71-L88】.

source.title: Arkansas Code § 19-12-112 - Creation of Medicaid Expansion Program Account

evidence_item.claim_summary: Ark. Code § 19-12-117 establishes the Arkansas Tobacco Settlement Commission, lists its members including directors of economic development, education, higher education, DHS, and Health, plus appointees, and authorizes it to monitor and evaluate expenditures and hire third-party evaluators【476407663690441†L71-L129】.

source.title: Arkansas Code § 19-12-117 - Establishment of the Arkansas Tobacco Settlement Commission

evidence_item.claim_summary: Ark. Code § 19-5-1118 establishes the Prevention and Cessation Program Account and provides that the account shall consist of moneys transferred from the Tobacco Settlement Program Fund and shall be used by the Department of Health for the purposes set out in § 19-12-109【175434792516377†L71-L80】.

source.title: Arkansas Code § 19-5-1118 - Prevention and Cessation Program Account

evidence_item.claim_summary: Ark. Code § 23-61-101 establishes the State Insurance Department as a division of the Department of Commerce, states its purpose is to serve and protect the public interest through enforcement of insurance laws, and describes its primary mission of consumer protection through insurer solvency and market conduct regulation【115366805496236†L75-L90】.

Ark. Code § 23-61-103 outlines powers and duties of the Insurance Commissioner, including enforcement of the Arkansas Insurance Code, licensing insurers and producers, regulating premium rates and insurer solvency, and conducting investigations【157841192112756†L74-L90】.

source.title: Arkansas Code § 23-61-103 - Powers and Duties of the Insurance Commissioner

evidence_item.claim_summary: The 2025 PASSE quarterly report notes that a 2.5% premium tax on health insurance plans has generated $194 million in nonfederal matching funds to reduce the general fund need for the PASSE program【922699166651308†L76-L82】.

The DFA County Aid manual explains that general revenue in the County Aid Fund is distributed 75% equally among the seventy-five counties and 25% based on population; distributions are made within ten days after the close of each calendar month【270363377152734†L22-L30】.

source.title: County Aid - DFA Budget Manual
source.issuing_body: Arkansas Department of Finance and Administration

evidence_item.claim_summary: Ark. Code § 26-26-310 requires county collectors to certify the amount of property tax reduction and directs the Chief Fiscal Officer and Treasurer of State to distribute Property Tax Relief Trust Fund proceeds to counties monthly based on their proportionate share; ninety-six percent of funds must be distributed to taxing entities and four percent retained as the county collector's commission【462707022258521†L123-L134】. It also requires distribution of two million dollars to counties and two million dollars to municipalities each year【462707022258521†L160-L175】.

source.title: Arkansas Code § 26-26-310 - Certification of amount of property tax reduction

evidence_item.claim_summary: Ark. Code § 26-18-101 declares that the chapter shall be known as the Arkansas Tax Procedure Act, forming the general procedural framework for the administration of state taxes【182534216742178†L72-L75】.

source.title: Arkansas Code § 26-18-101 - Arkansas Tax Procedure Act

evidence_item.claim_summary: 2 CFR § 200.501 requires a single or program-specific audit for any non-Federal entity expending $1,000,000 or more in Federal awards; it specifies audit and program-specific audit options and exemptions for entities spending less than $1,000,000【470131931365652†L308-L347】.

source.title: 2 CFR Part 200 Subpart F - Audit Requirements

evidence_item.claim_summary: Ark. Code § 23-115-102 declares that net proceeds of lotteries shall be used to fund scholarships and grants to Arkansas citizens and to supplement, not supplant, nonlottery educational resources【881816811921520†L74-L82】.

Ark. Code § 23-115-801 requires the Office of the Arkansas Lottery to deposit net proceeds from the lottery into the Lottery Scholarship Trust Account by the fifteenth of each month and to make funds available for various scholarship programs as specified in § 23-115-801(b)(1)(B)【666965105895442†L94-L118】.

field_validation.validating_entity: U.S. Office of Management and Budget

research_notes: Partial dataset due to time and complexity; processed some seeds.
